column2: We had some bird's-eyes of the cities and parks; a lot of lovely views of streets, of buildings, outside and in, and some of those gorgeous gardens, and, most important of all, of the women themselves.

column2: But it's got to be done somehow; the rest of the world needs to know about that country.

column2: There were three of us, classmates and friends--Terry O. Nicholson (we used to call him the Old Nick, with good reason), Jeff Margrave, and I, Vandyck Jennings.
column3: There were three of us, classmates and friends-Terry o Nicholson (we used to call him the Old Nick, with good reason), Jeff Margrave, and I, Vandyck Jennings.

column2: All of us were interested in science.
column3: All of us were interested in science.

column2: He used to make all kinds of a row because there was nothing left to explore now, only patchwork and filling in, he said.
column3: He used to make all kinds of a row because there was nothing left to explore now, only patchwork and filling in, he said.

column2: He filled in well enough--he had a lot of talents--great on mechanics and electricity.
column3: He filled in well enough-he had a lot of talents-great on mechanics and electricity.

column2: Jeff Margrave was born to be a poet, a botanist--or both--but his folks persuaded him to be a doctor instead.
column3: Jeff Margrave was born to be a poet, a botanist-or both-but his folks persuaded him to be a doctor instead.

column2: He was a good one, for his age, but his real interest was in what he loved to call "the wonders of science."
column3: He was a good one, for his age, but his real interest was in what he loved to call "the wonders of science."

column2: Terry was strong on facts--geography and meteorology and those; Jeff could beat him any time on biology, and I didn't care what it was they talked about, so long as it connected with human life, somehow.
column3: Terry was strong on facts-geography and meteorology and those; Jeff could beat him any time on biology, and I didn't care what it was they talked about, so long as it connected with human life, somehow.

column2: There are few things that don't.

column2: And as we got farther and farther upstream, in a dark tangle of rivers, lakes, morasses, and dense forests, with here and there an unexpected long spur running out from the big mountains beyond, I noticed that more and more of these savages had a story about a strange and terrible Woman Land in the high distance.

column2: Up yonder, "Over there,"
column3: Up yonder, "Over there,"

column2: Way up--was all the direction they could offer, but their legends all agreed on the main point--that there was this strange country where no men lived--only women and girl children.
column3: Way up--was all the direction they could offer, but their legends all agreed on the main point-that there was this strange country where no men lived-only women and girl children.

column2: It was dangerous, deadly, they said, for any man to go there.
column3: It was dangerous, deadly, they said, for any man to go there.

column2: Yes--a good many--but they never came back.

column3: I happened to speak of that river to our last guide, a rather superior fellow with quick, bright eyes.

column3: He told me that there was another river-"over there, short river, sweet water, red and blue."

column3: Yes, he pointed to the river, and then to the southwestward. "River-good water-red and blue."

column3: May be indigo, Jeff suggested, with his lazy smile.

column2: It was early yet; we had just breakfasted; and leaving word that we'd be back before night, we got away quietly, not wishing to be thought too gullible if we failed, and secretly hoping to have some nice little discovery all to ourselves.
column3: It was early yet; we had just breakfasted; and leaving word that we'd be back before night, we got away quietly, not wishing to be thought too gullible if we failed, and secretly hoping to have some nice little discovery all to ourselves.

column2: We saw--I can't remember now how much of this we noted then and how much was supplemented by our later knowledge, but we could not help seeing this much, even on that excited day--a land in a state of perfect cultivation, where even the forests looked as if they were cared for; a land that looked like an enormous park, only it was even more evidently an enormous garden.
